prompt: <description>Part 1: Creating the base part for a rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom Construct a rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom. Begin by creating a new coordinate system at the origin of the CAD model with Euler angles (0.0, 0.0, -90.0) and a translation vector of (0.0, 0.375, 0.0). This will position the part in the desired location and orientation for further operations. 1.1 Create the sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system. The sketch should have one face (face_1) composed of a single loop (loop_1) with 4 lines (line_1, line_2, line_3, and line_4). 1.1.1 Line_1: Begin with a line at (0.0, 0.0) and extend it to (0.75, 0.0). 1.1.2 Line_2: From the endpoint of line_1, create a line to (0.75, 0.1875). 1.1.3 Line_3: Extend line_2 to (0.0, 0.1875). 1.1.4 Lastly, complete the loop by connecting line_3 to line_1. This creates a closed rectangle. 1.2 After completing the sketch, scale it with a factor of 0.75. 1.3 Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch according to the coordinate system, defined by the Euler angles and translation vector provided earlier. The 3D sketch should now appear in its proper orientation and position. 1.4 Extrude the 3D sketch along its normal vector to a depth of 0.0938. There should be no extrusion in the opposite direction. Part 2: Creating a second part to the rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom Create the second part of the rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. This part will be created using an existing coordinate system, whose parameters are derived from Part 1's coordinate system, employing the same Euler angles (0.0, 0.0, -90.0) and a translation vector of (0.0, 0.375, 0.0). 2.1 Develop the sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system (from Part 1), following the same structure as Part 1: Create face_1 with a single loop_1 that has 4 lines (line_1, line_2, line_3, and line_4). 2.2 Scale the sketch by 0.75 after sketch creation. 2.3 In order to position the new sketched part adjacently, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch based on the coordinate system as defined previously. 2.4 Extrude the 3D sketch along its normal vector with a depth of 0.0938. No extrusion should be done in the opposite direction. 2.5 Now, join the newly created part to the initial part from Part 1. Part 3: Creating the final part for a rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom Create the last part of the rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Start by using the same existing coordinate system with Euler angles (0.0, 0.0, -90.0) and a translation vector of (0.0, 0.375, 0.0) as in Part 2. 3.1 Repeat step 2.1 for Sketch creation (face_1, loop_1, 4 lines: line_1, line_2, line_3, and line_4). 3.2 Scale the newly created sketch to 0.75 of the original size. 3.3 Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch with respect to the coordinate system. 3.4 Extrude the 3D sketch along its normal vector to a depth of 0.375. 3.5 Finally, join this new part with the previous one you created in Part 2. Your final model should be a rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Construct a rectangular prism with three circular cutouts Begin by creating a new coordinate system for part 1 with the following parameters: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.1748, 0.0] Create the first face of the sketch and add the following loops: 1. Loop 1: Draw a line from (0.0, 0.0) to (0.75, 0.0), then another line from (0.75, 0.0) to (0.75, 0.3871), then another line from (0.75, 0.3871) to (0.0, 0.3871), and finally a line from (0.0, 0.3871) to (0.0, 0.0) to close the loop. This forms a rectangle. 2. Loop 2: Draw a circle with a center at (0.1231, 0.1929) and a radius of 0.0534. This is the first circular cutout. 3. Loop 3: Draw a circle with a center at (0.2665, 0.1929) and a radius of 0.0791. This is the second circular cutout. 4. Loop 4: Draw a circle with a center at (0.4962, 0.1929) and a radius of 0.0534. This is the third circular cutout. 5. Loop 5: Draw a circle with a center at (0.6865, 0.1929) and a radius of 0.0354. Extrude the 2D sketch along the normal direction with a depth of 0.1748 units. The scaling parameter for the sketch can be set to 0.75. This will create a 3D solid model. Part 2: Construct two cylinders connected by a cylindrical tube Begin by creating a new coordinate system for part 2 with the following parameters: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0697, 0.1748, 0.1137] Create the first face of the sketch and add the following loops for the larger cylinder: 1. Loop 1: Draw a circle with a center at (0.0534, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0534. 2. Loop 2: Draw a circle with a center at (0.0534, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0389. This forms the top of the larger cylinder. Create a new face for the second cylinder and add the following loops: 1. Loop 1: Draw a circle with a center at (0.1968, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0791. 2. Loop 2: Draw a circle with a center at (0.1968, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0608. This forms the top of the smaller cylinder. Create another new face for the connecting tube and add the following loops: 1. Loop 1: Draw a circle with a center at (0.6168, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0354. 2. Loop 2: Draw a circle with a center at (0.6168, 0.0791) and a radius of 0.0257. Extrude the 2D sketches along the normal direction with appropriate depths for each of the cylindrical shapes. The scaling parameter for the sketches can be set to the values provided in the JSON. This will create a 3D solid model of two cylinders connected by a cylindrical tube. Once all parts are constructed, they will combine to form the final rectangular metal plate with four holes. The dimensions of the intermediate parts and the final shape are provided in the JSON.</description>
